descriptions.content:
The marker པ་ (or its variant བ་[1]) is by far the most common nominalizer. It is much more widely used in Literary than in Spoken Tibetan. The function of the head noun must be determined by default. From the syntactic functions that feature in the relative clause, we can use a process of elimination to identify the head noun’s function, which may be: subject, object, adverbials indicating time, place, instrument or manner, or noun complement, etc.

  • ལུག་རྣམས་ཆུ་ལོག་གིས་ཁྱེར་བའི་རྫི་བོ། “The shepherd whose sheep were carried away by the current…”
  • བུ་གཅིག་པུ་ཤི་བའི་མ་བཞིན་དུ། “Like a mother whose only son has died…”
  • ཆོས་ཐོབ་པའི་མི་ལུས་ཤིག “A human body that has received Dharma instruction…”
  • བུ་སྐྱེ་པའི་ཉི་མ་དེ། “The day when the boy was born…”
  • ནད་གསོ་བར་བྱེད་པའི་གཉེན་པོ། “The antidote that cures illnesses…”
  • ཁམས་ལ་གནོད་པའི་ཟས། “Food that injures the health…”
  • གང་ལ་སྙིང་སྟོབས་མཆོག་མངའ་བའི་རྣལ་འབྱོར་པ་དེ། “That yogin who possesses remarkable courage…”

[1] See the table that lays out the uses of these variants. (xxlink table Variant Written Forms)
